abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and the institutional development
            impact substantial. The main lessons convey the following:
            1) although the project made great strides in shifting
            investment decisions from the Government to the community,
            active engagement in project implementation by the
            communities did not occur until completion of facilities,
            and the subsequent transfer of operations, and management,
            often taking two, to three years as of the initial request
            submission for a water subproject, and obviously leading to
            a sense of disempowerment among the communities. It is thus
            suggested that the Directorate of Water Works may want to
            learn from recent innovations in having communities more
            involved in the procurement, and construction process; 2) a
            clear assessment of the supply capacity, both in terms of
            financial, and physical resources, and a flexible
            communications campaign should not only generate community
            demand, but provide supply responsiveness to reach targeted
            areas; 3) while the project showed that subsidy-free
            household sanitation is possible, new methods to replicate
            this approach should be developed, enhancing the challenges
            of coordinated work within the ministries of education,
            health, and water, and defining clearer hygienic baseline
            indicators; 4) social intermediation address the need to
            guide communities on issues such as financial management,
            tariff setting, hygiene and sanitation promotion, and
            operations and maintenance, by improving linkages to
            appropriate sources; and, 5) government, and donor
            partnerships underline the fact that project success was
            built on the basis of institutional partnerships, through a
            programmatic approach.
